Award.AbstractNarration:
Random thermal fluctuations can form knots in polymers such as DNA much like shaking headphones can cause knots in the cord. As a result, knots are common in long polymer chains. Knots also can be created by fluid flow. The objective of this project is to perform experiments that uncover how a knot is formed in a flow and how it is removed after formation. Broadly speaking, knotted polymers are important both to fundamental problems in biology and to applied topics in biotechnology. The immediate technological impacts of this problem lie in two emerging long-read genomics technologies: genome mapping and nanopore sequencing. Knotting in DNA also has a broader importance in biology, in particular for regulation of the genome.

This project experimentally addresses two key scientific questions related to knotting of long polymers, using DNA as a model system. The first part focuses on how stalling DNA at a nanofluidic interface produces knots, focusing on developing mechanistic insights via fluorescence microscopy. The second part focuses on the transport properties of DNA knots. These experiments leverage nanochannels as a “hydrodynamic microscope” to isolate the hydrodynamic interactions within the knot from hydrodynamic interactions between the knot and the rest of the chain. Through this work, graduate students on the project will receive training in clean-room fabrication methods, fluorescence microscopy, image processing, and the theories of hydrodynamics and polymer physics. This project also involves a K-12 outreach project to develop science fair projects related to the research for high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Knots are a familiar object in our daily lives, from the simple knots you use to tie your shoes to the more complex knots used for sailing. Polymers, which are large molecules that consist of many repeat chemical units, can also form knots at the macromolecular scale. The knots can form simply due to the thermal energy of the fluid containing the polymer, or they can be created by active processes such as fluid flow. DNA, the molecule that encodes the genetic makeup of every living organism, is an especially important polymer that can form knots. Regulation of these knots is so important that there exists a set of enzymes called topoisomerases that control the topology of DNA in cells. Knotting also plays a confounding role in next-generation genomics technologies that require stretching out DNA to observe sequence-dependent features of the molecule.

This project used experiments and computer simulations to understand how knots move along DNA molecules. The experiments leveraged a microfluidic technology known as the "knot factory", which was fabricated using the same technologies used to create computer chips, to create large complex knots on DNA that can be visualized using fluorescence microscopy. The first part of the project probed the mechanism that a single knot moves on DNA, testing two hypotheses: (i) a self-reptation mechanism, where the DNA moves in a snake-like fashion along the knot, and (ii) knot breathing, where the knot opens and closes as it moves along the DNA. Experimental results suggested that the self-reptation mechanism was dominant based on the way that the random fluctuations fo the knot position evolved in time, but subsequent simulations showed that both mechanisms are active and simply using the evolution of the knot position in time is insufficient. The second part of the project measured the friction of the knot on DNA when constrained in a channel. The knot reduces the total length of the DNA molecule, which would reduce the overall friction. However, the knot also puts more DNA close to the channel walls, which would increase the overall friction. The experiments clearly showed that the wall friction contribution dominated. The third part of the project measured the interactions between two knots on a DNA molecule. The experiments showed that there is an attraction between the two knots, but they do not remain in close proximity or intertwine. The attraction for the confined knots is akin to what is observed for two knots on DNA that is stretched in flow, but the flow-based system (where the molecule is in tension) lead to knots that stay in close proximity for long times. This apparent contradiction was resolved by simulations of two knots on DNA molecules. For the simplest knot, the trefoil (which looks like a pretzel), two knots in DNA can intertwine down to very small channel sizes. However, the next most complicated knot topology only intertwines at channel sizes that are similar to the experiments. Since the knot factory produces large, complicated knots, the simulations confirmed the experimental result. Moreover, through careful control of the knot topology in the simulations and comparisons of intertwining in stretched double-knotted DNA, the suppression of intertwining was confirmed to be due to the channel walls suppressing the transverse fluctuations of the DNA.

This project involved a postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student, an undergraduate student, and two high school students. All these participants received training in advanced scientific skills, including high performance computation, microfabrication, fluorescence microscopy, and manipulation of large DNA molecules. This project also contributed to increasing the gender diversity of the scientific workforce; of the five participants, four of them identify as female. Training of this type at all educational stages is important for the maintenance of the technology workforce in the US.
